42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matchemphys.2025.130412" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matchemphys.2025.130412</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0254058425000586&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0020" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0020"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0020"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">A CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> heterostructure composite anode is constructed for high electrochemical performance sodium-ion battery.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite contains abundant oxygen vacancies.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Some active interfaces can provide more sodium storage sites and accelerate sodium-ion diffusion kinetics.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> anode has excellent electrochemical performance and has been cycled more than 500 times at 1&nbsp;C current density.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">A novel CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> heterostructure composite is constructed with oxygen vacancies via a convenient and green hydrothermal method combined with solid phase process for high electrochemical performance sodium-ion battery. The CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> heterostructure forms some active interfaces which can provide more sodium storage sites and accelerate sodium-ion diffusion kinetics. Thus, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> anode displays excellent electrochemical properties in Na-ion batteries including high sodium-ion diffusion coefficient (7.1303&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−12</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>), extrinsic pseudocapacitance contribution (67&nbsp;%) and specific discharge capacity (325.2 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>) at 0.1&nbsp;C current rate. In addition, a superior long cycling performance over 500 cycles even at a high current density (1&nbsp;C) have been presented and therefore our work is a good strategy for the application of titanium-based metal compounds in sodium-ion batteries.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="undfig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt="Image 1"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (440KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (440KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0254058425000458"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0254058424014718"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> heterostructure composite</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Active interface</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Diffusion coefficient</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Pseudocapacitance performance</span></div><div id="kwrd0030" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">In recent years, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have attracted much attention owing to the advantage of long life spans and high storage energy density and operating voltage [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>]. Nevertheless, the application of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) is limited as its lithium resources and high costs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>]. In contrast, sodium-ion battery (SIBs) will be as alternative energy storage devices for lithium-ion batteries owing to its abundant resources, low cost and high safe efficiency [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>]. It is generally recognized that the anode material directly affects the overall kinetic performance of sodium-ion batteries, such as rate performance and power density. Therefore, it has been as a research hotspot in order to seek high-performance anode materials for sodium ion storage.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">At present, a great variety of anode materials including carbonaceous materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>], transition-metal oxides [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>], and alloy materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>] have been reported for SIBs. Among them, transition-metal oxides can exhibit some excellent properties such as optical, electrical and magnetic properties owing to their special crystal structures [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>]. Particularly titanium dioxides (TiO<sub>2</sub>), have been attracted attention due to its rich polymorphism and enough condition to storage ample sodium-ions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>]. Because the kinetic mass diffusion of rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> is slow, researchers have rarely compared it to the high sodium storage properties of anatase TiO<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. In addition, the development of rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> is limited due to low electronic conductivity resulting in an inferior rate capability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. In order to solve these shortcomings of rutile TiO<sub>2</sub>, various of modification strategies have been devoted including nanoscale design [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>], conductive carbon loading [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>] and heteroatoms doping and composite [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>]. In current, heteroatom doping as an effective way to improve the conductivity of TiO<sub>2</sub> has focused a great deal of attention. However, composite material, particularly rare-earth metal, is rarely reported, which is mainly attributed to the lack of stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">Cerium dioxide (CeO<sub>2</sub>) with a fluorite structure can be formed by cerium cation at face-centered cubic positions, which can provide more interstitial paths for ion diffusion. Moreover, it also indicates that CeO<sub>2</sub> can be easily reduced to CeO<sub>2-x</sub>, which is mainly attributed to the redox behavior between Ce<sup>4+</sup> and Ce<sup>3+</sup>. So, it can provide more sodium storage sites and play a role in catalysing a certain electrochemical kinetic reaction rate [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>]. And then, cerium oxide with oxygen storage capacity (OSC) can also easily form the labile oxygen vacancies and relatively high mobility [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. Qian et al. designed high electrochemical performance Ce doped α-FeOOH nanorods which the Ce doping effectively optimize electronic conductivity so as to accelerate diffusion kinetics of Li-ion and enhance structure stability via hydrothermal method along with acid-treatment process for the first [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>]. Whereafter, rare earth element Ce due to the large radius has attracted much attention which can expand in favour of providing more lattice space for lithium intercalation and de-intercalation of crystal lattice, thus a large number of Ce doping electrode materials have been reported including Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>], LiMnPO<sub>4</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>], Li<sub>4</sub>Ti<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>], SrLi<sub>2</sub>Ti<sub>6</sub>O<sub>14</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>] and SnS<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. However, the composite materials via combining different components owing to excellent electronic properties phase can significantly improve the electronic properties so as to effectively improve the electrochemical properties [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. According to previous investigation, researches about composites as anode for SIBs have been gradually attracting attention, however, CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composites have rarely reported.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">It is currently widely recognized that different strategies including solid-phase method [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>], hydrothermal method [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>], chemistry [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]&amp;electrochemistry method [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>], sol-gel method [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>], and so on for constructing metal-metal oxide composites will be particularly important for their structure and properties. In this present work, we successfully construct a CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anode material in order to improve the electrochemical performances of rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> anode for sodium-ion batteries via a convenient hydrothermal method combined with solid phase process. The effects of cerium oxide on crystal structure and electrochemical properties of rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> have been investigated, and the sodium storage properties are well improved compared to commercial TiO<sub>2</sub>.</div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experiment</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Synthesis of CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite material</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> was synthesized via a convenient hydrothermal method combined with high-temperature solid phase process. Firstly, 3.4&nbsp;mL tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) and 0.4&nbsp;mL concentrated hydrochloric acid were mixed well-distributed. Then, 13.6&nbsp;mL absolute ethanol and 0.2&nbsp;mL deionized water were mixed together. After that, two solutions were mixed well to obtain a stable TiO<sub>2</sub> soliquid. After stirring to form a homogeneous soliquid, the mixture was kept at 160&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h in a vacuum oven. Then, the obtained white substance was collected through centrifugation, and washed several times with ethanol respectively. At last, the final TiO<sub>2</sub> white powder was obtained by further drying under vacuum at 70&nbsp;°C overnight.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">In order to obtain CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite material, CeO<sub>2</sub> and above mentioned TiO<sub>2</sub> white powder were mixed in the alcohol solvent with the mass percent to 5&nbsp;%, 10&nbsp;%, and 15&nbsp;% (CeO<sub>2</sub>:TiO<sub>2</sub>). Next, the mixed white powder was put into an alumina crucible and calcined at 800&nbsp;°C for 10&nbsp;h, then, the white sample were obtained after grinding. As compared, the sample selected for commercial pure TiO<sub>2</sub> was signed C–TiO<sub>2。</sub>A structure diagram of the design process of the CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite material is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr1.jpg" height="232" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (301KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (301KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Structure diagram of design process of CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite matrix.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">The XRD patterns of C–TiO<sub>2</sub>, 5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> and 15&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> samples are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a. As can be deduced from the curves, the primary diffraction peaks of the four samples are all indexed to rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> (JCPDS No.21-1276). Besides, some addition peaks of composite material can also be identified as CeO<sub>2</sub> ((JCPDS No.43-1002), indicating that CeO<sub>2</sub> is successfully composited with TiO<sub>2</sub>. And when the more elemental Ce is added, the main diffraction peaks gradually become weaker and wider. According to Scherrer formula, it is shown that although CeO<sub>2</sub> composition reduces the crystallinity, it tightens the grain structure of the rutile TiO<sub>2</sub>. Raman spectrum is to further investigate the molecular skeleton structure of the CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b, these bands B<sub>1g</sub> at 146.5&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, E<sub>g</sub> at 240.9 and 449.9&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, and A<sub>1g</sub> at 612.5&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> corresponding to vibrational modes of rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> are clearly observed respectively. It is known that the E<sub>g</sub> mode at 449.9&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> represents a symmetric stretching vibration of Ti–O [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>]. Then, the more cerium oxide is present, the Eg (449.9&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>) mode shifts towards higher waves and the main diffraction peak broadens is also enhanced. This illustrates that a red shift phenomena of the Eg peak has been increased the bonding energy of Ti–O structure due to cerium oxide with oxygen storage capacity which is conductive to undergo a more stable redox reactions on the surface of titanium dioxide [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr2.jpg" height="563" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (848KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (848KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (a, b) and Raman spectra (c, d) of 5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 15&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, and C–TiO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">To understand the superiority of CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite, the electrochemical performances of 5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 15&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> and C–TiO<sub>2</sub> composites as anodes in sodium-ion batteries is investigated. The initial charge-discharge curves at different rates for all the materials are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a–d. Based on the results, the similar initial discharge curves of these four anodes indicate that CeO<sub>2-x</sub> surface modification TiO<sub>2</sub> has little effect on the electrochemical reaction process, however, the 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anode shows the highest initial discharge specific capacities of 325.2 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 218 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 147.6 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 132.5 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 104.8 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> and 67.8 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> at current densities of 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, 2C and 5C, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr3.jpg" height="1015" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Initial charge-discharge curves at different rates (a)5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>,(b) 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, (c)15&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, (d)C–TiO<sub>2</sub> (e) Cycling performances at 1C, (f) Rate performances of 5&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 15&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, C–TiO<sub>2</sub> electrodes, (g)Initial charge-discharge curve of 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> at 0.1C, (h) Nyquist plots.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">To verify the unique advantages of the 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anode materials for SIBs, we investigate the cycle performance at different current densities (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3e and Fig. S1</span></span></a> a) and charge and discharge curves at different cycle time have been shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S1b–e</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e, obviously, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anode displays a high reversible discharge specific capacity of 83.4 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> and 69.4&nbsp;% capacity retention at 1&nbsp;C after 500 cycles. As expected, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f shows that 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anode for SIBs delivers the best rate performance with discharge specific capacities of 325.2mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 197.7mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 156.4 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 132.5mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, 104.8mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>, and 67.8mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> at a current rate of 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, 2C and 5C, respectively. More importantly, when the charge and discharge current return to 0.1C, the discharge specific capacity can be recover to 189.2 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> without too much loss. This means that some active interfaces between CeO<sub>2-x</sub> and TiO<sub>2</sub> have been formed which can provide more sodium storage sites and accelerate sodium-ion diffusion kinetics so as to achieve high discharge specific capacity and excellent cycling performance. For better understanding of the reaction mechanism of CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anodes for SIBs, we investigate the relationship of charging and discharging voltage and working time in the initial charge-discharge curve of the 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anodes at 0.1C current rate and the charge-discharge curves have been divided into four regions (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g). Firstly, the voltage drops to 1.0&nbsp;V due to pseudocapacitive sodium-ion adsorption, SEI film formation and irreversible adsorption. Then, the plateaus as it drops from 1.0&nbsp;V to 0.3&nbsp;V, which is corresponding to cathodic decomposition plateau of the electrolyte at the surface and the voltage drop from 0.3V to 0.01&nbsp;V which is due to Na<sup>+</sup> insertion and structure rearrangement and disproportionation reaction, consistent well with previous reports. At last, the voltage increases from 0.01&nbsp;V to 2.5&nbsp;V ascribing to the reversible Na<sup>+</sup> extraction process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">To further investigate electrochemical reaction kinetics of CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anodes, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>h) is analyzed. It indicates that all of the Nyquist plots mainly consist of three parts including Rs as the internal resistance embodied in the small intercept at the high-frequency region, R<sub>ct</sub> as charge-transfer impedance on the electrode-electrolyte interface embodied in the semicircle in the high-frequency region, and Z<sub>w</sub>’ as the sodium-ion diffusion resistance in solid electrode embodied in the sloping line at the low-frequency region [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>]. In addition, the ion diffusion coefficient (D<sub>Na+</sub>) is calculated by equations <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd1" name="bfd1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd2" name="bfd2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a>).<span class="display"><span id="fd1" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>T</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>A</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>n</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>4</mn></msup><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>F</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>4</mn></msup><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x1A1;</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>w</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="29.136ex" height="3.125ex" viewBox="0 -896.2 12544.8 1345.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.043ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(764,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4E"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" is="true">2</mn></msup><msubsup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">ơ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">w</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="fd2" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Z</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>,</mo></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>Rs</mtext><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>Rct</mtext><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x1A1;</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>w</mi></msub><msup
