transform="translate(611,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2C"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1186,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2242,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-52"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-73" x="736" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3595,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4596,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-52"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-63" x="736" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-74" x="1181" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7389,0)"><g is="true"><text font-family="STIXGeneral,'Arial Unicode MS',serif" stroke="none" transform="scale(55.199) matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)">ơ</text></g><g is="true" transform="translate(433,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-77"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8434,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-57"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1028,363)"><g is="true"><text font-family="STIXGeneral,'Arial Unicode MS',serif" stroke="none" transform="scale(39.032) matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)">‐</text></g><g is="true" transform="translate(187,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(541,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(895,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Z</mi><mo is="true">,</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mtext is="true">Rs</mtext><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mtext is="true">Rct</mtext><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">ơ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">w</mi></msub><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">W</mi><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">‐</mo><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Z</mi><mo is="true">,</mo></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mtext is="true">Rs</mtext><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mtext is="true">Rct</mtext><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">ơ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">w</mi></msub><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">W</mi><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">‐</mo><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>In this equation, A is to indicate the specific surface area of the electrode, ơ<sub>w</sub> is the Warburg factor, and C is representative of the concentration of sodium ions. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl1" name="btbl1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a> represents that the D<sub>Na&nbsp;+</sub>&nbsp;value of the 10&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anode (7.1303&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−12</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>) is higher than that of the 5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> (6.2558&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>), 15&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> (7.4854&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>) and C–TiO<sub>2</sub> (4.0378&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>). It can be found that the introduction of CeO<sub>2-x</sub> improves the sodium ion diffusion coefficient (D<sub>Na+</sub>). And then, The Nyquist plots of the CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite anode with different the mass percent of CeO<sub>2-x</sub> illustrate that the R<sub>ct</sub> value of 10&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> is only 242&nbsp;Ω, which is smaller than that of the other CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> and pure TiO<sub>2</sub> (C–TiO<sub>2</sub>) anodes. Hence, it can be inferred that 10&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> has the highest conductivity and electrochemical activity.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl1"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="tspara0010"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. Comparison of EIS parameters of 5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 15&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, C–TiO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">sample</th><th scope="col">R<sub>s</sub>(Ω)</th><th scope="col">R<sub>ct</sub>(Ω)</th><th scope="col">D<sub>Na+</sub>(cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup>)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub></td><td class="align-char">20.1</td><td class="align-char">440</td><td class="align-left">6.2558&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−13</sup></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">10&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub></td><td class="align-char">22.8</td><td class="align-char">242</td><td class="align-left">7.1303&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−12</sup></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">15&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub></td><td class="align-char">19.5</td><td class="align-char">390</td><td class="align-left">7.4854&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−13</sup></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C–TiO<sub>2</sub></td><td class="align-char">17.3</td><td class="align-char">630</td><td class="align-left">4.0378&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−13</sup></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a–d displays the CV curves of CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite and pure TiO<sub>2</sub> anodes with different mass ratio of CeO<sub>2-x</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. Meanwhile, a sharp peak is observed at low scanning speed cathodic process under 0.09&nbsp;V and then disappear in the subsequent strong scanning speed (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e), this is due to the fact that CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> has a specific structure which allows some of the Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;to be released [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. And the other part of Na<sup>+</sup> in the CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> anode is further released around 0.67&nbsp;V, whereas, Na<sup>+</sup> will be re-intercalated around 0.41&nbsp;V. The curves overlap very well, indicating excellent electrochemical stability. Comparison with the CV curve of C–TiO<sub>2</sub>, two obvious oxidation peak around 1.6&nbsp;V and 2.16&nbsp;V and a reduction around 1.92&nbsp;V is observed, then no redox peaks are found in other composites, this may be because capacity decay is irreversible [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr4.jpg" height="1011" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. CV curves for the first five cycles at 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> sweep rate (a) 5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, (b) 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, (c)15&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, (d) C–TiO<sub>2,</sub> (e) CV curves at different sweep rates from 0.1 to 10&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, (f) b-value analysis using the relationship between the peak currents and the scan rates, (g) Contribution ratio of the capacitive and diffusion-controlled charges at different scan rates, (h) capacitive contribution to the current of 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> at 10&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> sweep rate.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">The storage mechanism of sodium ions was explored by CV curves to further illustrate the reaction kinetics of CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> anodes. It can be found that the CV curve changes significantly with increasing scan rate, which can be attributed to charge transfer resistance or diffusion constraints. The linear relationship between the logarithm of the scan rate and the peak redox current was observed by testing (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f). As shown in equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd3" name="bfd3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(3)</span></span></a> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>]:<span class="display"><span id="fd3" class="formula"><span class="label">(3)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.337ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 3159.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2180,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-62"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>In this equation, <em>v</em> is sweep rate, <em>i</em> represents the peak current, <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are constants. By calculation, b values of 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> is 0.88 (cathodic) and 0.78 (anodic) and C–TiO<sub>2</sub> sample is 0.87 (cathodic) and 0.77 (anodic), respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2d</span></span></a>). Typically, A value of b equal to 0.5 will mainly indicate a diffusion controlled process, and A value of b (equal 1.0) suggests a capacitive controlled process for the sodium-ion storage [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>]. The sample b value of between 0.5 and 1 can display the pseudo-capacitance characteristic between the typical behaviors of batteries and capacitors [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>]. And the characteristic of pseudo-capacitance is benefit to the rapid transmission of ions. Equations <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd4" name="bfd4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(4)</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fd5" name="bfd5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fd5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(5)</span></span></a>) allow us to determine how well the two mechanisms contribute to the total charge storage.<span class="display"><span id="fd4" class="formula"><span class="label">(4)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-4-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="16.258ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 7000 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2661,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3369,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4370,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5352,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="fd5" class="formula"><span class="label">(5)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-5-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>or</mtext><mspace width=&quot;0.25em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="22.774ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 9805.3 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6F"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-72" x="500" y="0"></use></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1143,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1488,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1989,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3913,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4970,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5952,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7822,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8822,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(528,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">or</mtext><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-5"><math><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">or</mtext><mspace width="0.25em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>Where k<sub>2</sub>v<sup>1/2</sup> corresponds to the contribution of intercalation/deintercalation effects [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>], and k<sub>1</sub><em>v</em> represents the contribution of the surface capacitive effects.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">The calculation shows that stored charge for 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> is 17&nbsp;% and 67&nbsp;% at 0.1&nbsp;mV<sup>−1</sup> and 10&nbsp;mV<sup>−1</sup>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>h), However, the C–TiO<sub>2</sub> capacitance contribution is low, 14&nbsp;% at 0.1&nbsp;mV<sup>−1</sup>, even though it is only 62&nbsp;% at 10&nbsp;mV<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2f</span></span></a>). The large pseudo-capacitive contribution may be correlated with defects formation between CeO<sub>2-x</sub> and TiO<sub>2</sub> in the CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite structure during the charge and discharge process, which cause the 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> to possess excellent electrochemical performance at high current densities.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a> depicts the SEM images of commercial pure TiO<sub>2</sub> (C–TiO<sub>2</sub>) and CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composites with different mass ratio of CeO<sub>2-x</sub>. As seen, the C–TiO<sub>2</sub> is constructed by irregularity nanoparticles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d), however, CeO<sub>2-x</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composites prepared in this experiment display the scale morphology of rough sphericity, and the morphology becomes increasingly coarse with the increase of CeO<sub>2-x</sub> content (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a-c). It can be assumed that the generation of these rough particles is the result of some CeO<sub>2</sub> grains attached to the surface of TiO<sub>2</sub> spheres and moreover, for 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite, CeO<sub>2</sub> maintains a nanoscale grain size with a very homogeneous distribution so as to manifests itself in surface compression of the crystal lattice and form a large number of highly active sites leading to a significant increase in conductivity and sodium-ion diffusion rate of electrode materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. Nevertheless, the spherical surface collapses slightly when the CeO<sub>2-x</sub> content rise to 15&nbsp;wt%, which can be attributed to higher cerium slightly change the original phase structure and it bright about a vast affect the electrochemical reaction kinetics. By performing TEM and HRTEM tests on 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, it is found that a lattice spacing of 0.32&nbsp;nm corresponds to the (110) crystalline surface of titanium dioxide and a lattice spacing of 0.31&nbsp;nm corresponds to the (111) crystalline surface of cerium oxide (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g). It can be surmised that TiO<sub>2</sub> particles can enhance the electrical conductivity between them via forming a cerium oxide (CeO<sub>2-x</sub>) coating on the surface.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr5.jpg" height="356" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (756KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (756KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. SEM images of sample (a-d) 5&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, 15&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, and C–TiO<sub>2</sub> (e) EDS elemental mapping, (f) TEM, (g) HRTEM images of 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">In addition, the surface composition and elemental species of 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composites were investigated by means of XPS measurements (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a demonstrates the presence of the elements Ti, Ce and O and the Ti 2p spectrum has two dominant peaks (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b), corresponding to Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 for Ti<sup>4+</sup>. And two tiny peaks at 458.2&nbsp;eV and 463.7&nbsp;eV are assigned to Ti 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Ti 2p<sub>3/2</sub> of Ti<sup>3+</sup>, which is probably caused cerium oxide with the redox behavior between Ce<sup>4+</sup> and Ce<sup>3+</sup>, as reported in some previous researches [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. The Ce 3d spectra exhibits eight dominant peaks (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c) and the peaks at 900.2&nbsp;eV, 902.5&nbsp;eV, 906.3&nbsp;eV and 916.1&nbsp;eV correspond to the Ce 3d<sub>3/2</sub>, while the peaks at 881.7eV, 884.5eV, 888.6eV and 897.6eV are attributed to the Ce 3d<sub>5/2</sub> and two weak peaks at 884.2eV and 902.5eV manifest the presence of Ce<sup>3+</sup> ions, while six obvious peaks is assigned to the Ce<sup>4+</sup> ions, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. The measurement is further evidence that some oxygen vacancies have been formed by redox reaction of cerium oxide on the titanium dioxide surface. In the O1s spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d), The peaks at 529.7&nbsp;eV and 531.5&nbsp;eV correspond to Ti–O and surface –OH bonds, respectively. The above results indicates that the valence concentration deviation of the original cations can lead to a change in the charge state of the transition metal cations, which in turn will greatly change the electronic conductivity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>], and then the formation of certain oxygen vacancies in the material is possible to provide suitable pathways and more storage sites for sodium ion diffusion. Then, the Rietveld XRD patterns of C–TiO<sub>2</sub> and 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> based on <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a> illustrate that in the 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite structure, CeO<sub>2-x</sub> is a fluorite crystal structure (Fm3m) with a 0.54&nbsp;nm cell parameter and the existence of additional phases (Ce<sup>3+</sup>/<sup>4+</sup>) does not change the cellular parameters of the original TiO<sub>2</sub> (a&nbsp;=&nbsp;b&nbsp;=&nbsp;459&nbsp;nm,c&nbsp;=&nbsp;296&nbsp;nm) which means that CeO<sub>2-x</sub> and TiO2 are mainly arranged in the form of heterojunctions thereby significantly enhancing the kinetic rate of the anode active material in the sodium-ion battery during the electrochemical reactions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr6.jpg" height="492" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (593KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (593KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0254058425000586-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) XPS survey, (b) Ti 2p, (c) Ce 3d, (d) O 1s spectra of 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">In summary, cerium dioxide (CeO<sub>2-x</sub>) surface modification rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> composite is successfully synthesized via a convenient and green hydrothermal method combined with solid phase process and its sodium storage property is evaluated. When 10&nbsp;wt% CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> as anode material for sodium-ion battery, it can achieve an initial discharge capacity of 325.2 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;C and 218 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2&nbsp;C and a high reversible discharge specific capacity of 83.4 mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> and 69.4&nbsp;% capacity retention at 1&nbsp;C after 500 cycles. That is believed that the excellent electrochemical performances are attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies and the contribution of the extrinsic pseudo-capacitance which can facilitate the electron and mass transportation. In addition, the heterostructure included in the 10&nbsp;wt%CeO<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> composite can provide a large number of reaction sites and accelerate sodium-ion electrochemical kinetic reaction rate.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><strong>Lan Li:</strong> Writing – original draft, Resources, Investigation, Data curation. <strong>Runna Shi:</strong> Methodology, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Xueqin Jing:</strong> Validation, Investigation. <strong>Tingting Qu:</strong> Investigation, Formal analysis. <strong>Lin Wang:</strong> Validation, Resources, Funding acquisition, Formal analysis. <strong>Xiaoshi Lang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Validation, Supervision, Funding acquisition, Formal analysis. <strong>Kedi Cai:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Resources, Project administration, Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledges</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" Dai</div><div id="ref-id-sref7" class="title text-m">NASICON-structure Na<sub>3+x</sub>MnV<sub>x</sub>Ti<sub>1-x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C cathode for sodium-ion battery with excellent cycling performance and high specific capacity</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Mater.     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>

<script data-cfasync="false">
      (function initOneTrust()  {
        const monitor = {
  init: () => {},
  loaded: () => {},
};
        function enableGroup(group) {
  document.querySelectorAll(`script[type*="ot-${group}"]`).forEach(script => {
    script.type = 'text/javascript';
    document.head.appendChild(script);
  });
}
        function runOneTrustCookies(doClear, monitor) {
  const oneTrustConsentSdkId = 'onetrust-consent-sdk';
  const emptyNodeSelectors = 'h3.ot-host-name, h4.ot-host-desc, button.ot-host-box';
  const ariaLabelledByButtonNodes = 'div.ot-accordion-layout > button';
  const ariaAttribute = 'aria-labelledby';
  function adjustOneTrustDOM() {
    const oneTrustRoot = document.getElementById('onetrust-consent-sdk');

    /* remove empty nodes */
    [...(oneTrustRoot?.querySelectorAll(emptyNodeSelectors) ?? [])].filter(e => e.textContent === '').forEach(e => e.remove());

    /* remove invalid aria-labelledby values */
    oneTrustRoot?.querySelectorAll(ariaLabelledByButtonNodes).forEach(e => {
      const presentIdValue = e.getAttribute(ariaAttribute)?.split(' ').filter(label => document.getElementById(label)).join(' ');
      if (presentIdValue) {
        e.setAttribute(ariaAttribute, presentIdValue);
      }
    });
  }
  function observeOneTrustLoaded(shouldSetOTDefaults, isConsentPresent) {
    const cb = (mutationList, observer) => {
      const oneTrustRoot = mutationList.filter(mutationRecord => mutationRecord.type === 'childList' && mutationRecord.addedNodes.length).map(mutationRecord => [...mutationRecord.addedNodes]).flat().find(e => e.id === oneTrustConsentSdkId);
      if (oneTrustRoot && typeof OneTrust !== 'undefined') {
        monitor.loaded(true);
        OneTrust.OnConsentChanged(() => {
          const perfAllowed = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie.match('(^| )OptanonConsent=([^;]+)')?.[2])?.match('groups=([0-9:0|1,?]+)&?')?.[1]?.match('2:([0|1])')[1] === '1';
          if (perfAllowed) {
            enableGroup('performance');
          }
        });
        if (!isConsentPresent && (shouldSetOTDefaults || OneTrust.GetDomainData().ConsentModel.Name === 'implied consent')) {
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `1:1`);
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `2:1`);
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `3:1`);
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `4:0`);
        }
        document.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent('@sdtech/onetrust/loaded', {}));
        observer.disconnect();
        adjustOneTrustDOM();
      }
    };
    const observer = new MutationObserver(cb);
    observer.observe(document.querySelector('body'), {
      childList: true
    });
  }
  if (doClear) {
    document.cookie = 'OptanonAlertBoxClosed=; expires=Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 UTC; samesite=lax; path=/';
  }
  const isConsentPresent = !!decodeURIComponent(document.cookie.match('(^| )OptanonConsent=([^;]+)')?.[2])?.match('groups=([0-9:0|1,?]+)&?')?.[1];
  const shouldSetOTDefaults = 'false' === 'false' && !document.cookie?.match('OptanonAlertBoxClosed=');
  if (shouldSetOTDefaults) {
    const date = new Date();
    date.setFullYear(date.getFullYear() + 1);
    document.cookie = `OptanonAlertBoxClosed=${new Date().toISOString()}; expires=${date.toUTCString()}; samesite=lax; path=/; domain=sciencedirect.com`;
  }
  observeOneTrustLoaded(shouldSetOTDefaults, isConsentPresent, monitor);
  window.addOTScript = () => {
    const otSDK = document.createElement('script');
    otSDK.setAttribute('data-cfasync', 'false');
    otSDK.setAttribute('src', 'https://cdn.cookielaw.org/scripttemplates/otSDKStub.js');
    otSDK.setAttribute('data-document-language', 'true');
    otSDK.setAttribute('data-domain-script', '865ea198-88cc-4e41-8952-1df75d554d02');
    window.addOTScript = () => {};
    document.head.appendChild(otSDK);
    monitor.init();
  };
  window.addEventListener('load', () => window.addOTScript());
}
        if (document.location.host.match(/.sciencedirect.com$/)) {
          runOneTrustCookies(true, monitor);
        }
        else {
          window.addEventListener('load', (event) => {
            enableGroup('performance');
          });
        }
      }());
    </script>
